posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey dude!

I wonder how badly you want these 35 levels of Monk for SR, cuz they are somewhat hindering your power. If you went Monk 30 Fighter 4 CoT 6, you'd get +3 to all saves, WF:Kama (which you can swap for WF: Unarmed as a requirement for CoT and then use one of the CoT bonus feats to take it again), Divine Wrath, and +2 feats (besides the aforementioned WF:Kama). You could then take 4 Fighter and 4 CoT pre-epic and that would give you another BAB point AND you could use a CoT bonus feat to take EWS, making Fighter 5 unnecessary. If you swap some feats around, you can reach a higher strength, maybe reaching a lower SR for 2 Great Strengths (one in place of EWS and another in place of ISR or even in place of Epic Prowess, maintaining said SR and increasing only damage by 1).

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That's easy to answer, the difference between 35 and 30 levels of Monk is to be affected by mages on hard areas or not. Simple as that. That is why also the SR feats went first in the list and not last.

35 levels and early SR feats is the minimum if you want to stay fully competitive in level appropriate hard areas. the difference between 30 and 35 Monk levels is not 5 SR less but 7 because you loose also the bonus Monk feat that is used for it.

Damage and AB can be increased simply by going Half-Orc as i stated at the start but i found this one to be more balanced, that being said if you have trust in your abilities then by all means go for that. As it is now, the Bosses will affect you of course and some Archmages too, the rest of them will try to put up damage shiels if they have the time or simply melee you with their swords. With a full Monk 40 and 3 Sr feats for a total of 56 SR nothing sort of the Bosses will attempt to cast even a single spell on you. With 30 levels and 1 SR feat for a total of 42 SR (which is still good) you will be affected in hard level appropriate areas but you will be immune to all the rest of magelings.

Taking two more Gr. STR feats isnt possible except if you want to pass on the WF, EP, feats so we leave that out and taking one less Monk for one more Fighter is loosing the AS feat for taking it back with the extra Fighter feat but loosing a net 1 SR.

AB and Damage is still very good if you take into consideration the Monk attack schedule and the extra two attacks. Trust me when i say he hits like a truck, especially in the Half-Orc version of him.

Many people are not aware of the usefulness of the many monk levels and simply stop where improved evasion is gained. But the truth is that Monk's have lots to give especially after 16th level. You just need to know where to stop. If only for the mind affects immunity it is fully worth it to go for 20 Monk levels. When i post my Kensai you will see what i mean.

Thanks for the input Max.

This is a solid, well-balanced build, as you mentioned. With the ability to hit hard, and that eye-popping SR, it's hard to go wrong with him.

posts.author: Valerfor

First of all, welcome to the ECB Black Cobra!

Now to your questions,

1) I am aware of this aye, simply replacing the IC: Unarmed Strike with either of the Save Boosters will solve it. I would select Great Fortitude first as i did in the Half-Orcish version.

2) I took Fighter at 2nd lvl because with Monks you usually want to behave like a Fighter would for the first few lvls and dress in Full Plate and Shield. posts.content: I've not played a monk before, as I mentioned, so I'm not sure what happens during gameplay at higher levels - I feel the AC is very low and I'm wondering if I'm going to be relying on some abilities and use of features to deal with getting hit from physical attacks. Can someone give me some heads up on this, please?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That depends a lot on your environment, i do not have any idea what kind of PW Dor Maegling is, neither it's cap on items or if you can craft or simply find them. But if it serves you i can do a basic analysis for (+5) caped items and also give you the basis for Monk's strategies. Alright, here we go,

Basic AC calculation for (+5) item modules:  28 (Base) +6 (DEX) +5 (WIS) +4 (Haste) +5 (Robe) +5 (Sun Soul Boots) +5 (N/A Amulet) +5 (Deflection Cloak/Cape) = 63 AC (Half-Orc Version)

Conclusion for AC: 63 AC is on par with a full plate and shield warrior with access in full tumble and even slightly more than that. This is considered to be a good AC everywhere, although not ground-braking by any means. Some flexible warriors would have this kind AC plus the option for Expertise to raise it further at the cost of their AB but that would require an investment in your INT that you do not have currently. Instead what you do have is...

a) Monk Speed: Monk's 35th level of speed makes him faster than the eye (especially when combined with haste) can perceive and allows him to chose the ground for his battles, simply put, if a fight goes wrong for the Monk, he can simply escape and return when he is ready. He can most effectively also make hit-and-run tactics, often employing his stunning fists ability to great effect.

b) Empty Body: This ability which can not be dispelled, lasts for 35 Rounds each time and you can use it twice per day, before you need to rest. It gives you a net 50% concealment making half of the attacks who would otherwise penetrate your AC, hit thin air.

c) Great Offense: Lets leave the numbers speak here, you will have (8!) Attacks/Round (Haste and Flurry Of Blows) that each does some serious damage and all of you attacks have the Monk's progression (-3 instead of -5). Furthermore you willl have 35 uses for your Stunning Fist ability that can freeze an opponent for three rounds making him a sitting duck and of course Improved Knocckdown at your disposal. When you have this kind of offense, foes do not live long enough to do serious damage.

  Here are some basic strategy tips you will have to follow if you want to make great use og Monks in general...

1) Always try to buff your main stats. (STR > WIS > DEX > CON) in that order. You will possibly not be able to buff them at the cap (+12) using permanent items but you can for sure compine permanent buffs (items) wiith temporary ones (potions) to get the most out of them. Monks are like that, they need stats the most along with Paladins. Feed them well and they will make you happy.

2) Avoid clustered positions. NWN 1 has a bad understanding of character commands and often will leave you wide open without an input on your attack sequence, causing you to be flat-footed. Most player death's on inexperienced/ average players comes from that very reason. Flat-footed does not only means the loss of your DEX-based AC but a lot more, inclluding all of your Tumble AC as well. If you are involved in such a situation thne watch closely the upper left corner of your screen and make sure your character has commands (simple attacks/ ikd/ stunning fist) at all times. Do not click outside of the fight or a foe that you cannot reach, or else the computer will try to execute this move, it will find it impossible and then it will leave you with an empty attack sequence causing you to be flat-footed!

3) Use your active feats and abilities: Monk's have a variety of options, IKD, Stunning Fist, Empty Body and Flurry Of Blows. While it can be lot's of fun simply point your character in one direction and let him bash on opponents with his unarmed attacks you can always do better by taking the fight in your hands. Watch your combat log or simply observe the fight. Do you hit easily your opponents? If YES, then use Flurry Of Blows for more attacks! Do you face a mage/ cleric/ rogue? Then use your Stunning Fist! Do you face a particularly difficult opponent in melee? Then use Empty Body! The fight seems lost? Get away with your Monk Speed and heal up, then return using stealth or simply drink an invisibility potion then attack first using an opening move with two-or-three Stunning Attacks then quickly back away. Did you succeed? Then rush forward and finish him while he is a sitting duck! Don't forget your Stunning Fists, it is a powerful tool, especially with buffed wisdom. And IKD is dead-useful too.

  I hope i helped some, i cannot possibly transfer you all of my wisdom accumulated through years of hardcore playing, but these should suffice considering that this Monk is (although slightly less than a pure) very well protected. Most warriors would kill for even one of your class features and you have several in your disposal (SR 49, Mind-Effects Immunity, Empty Body, Monk Speed, Improved Evasion e.t.c) so make use of them. If however you do want some greater protection then we can re-arrange the build suited to your tastes since Dev. Crit. is not allowed there and we could incorporate both of the Expertise feats along with better starting WIS for even more AC. That build would be more balanced, somewhat like the first (Dwarven) version of it with slightly less AB/Dmg but also with way better defenses.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Yah, Empyre is close enough for what you need to know, Vecho.  To detail a bit more without posting a whole lot of statistical analysis from a spreadsheet table and further derailing this poor fellow's build (if you could construe Valerfor as being a poor fellow... a stretch! )...

A kukri has the 18-20 range, 2 wider than a kama.  But kama gets the monk progression so the 2 rolls (18, 19 or +10%) that can crit must hit before the crit can threaten, naturally, are offset EXACTLY by the monk progression (-3 BAB vs. -5 BAB = +2 AB or +10%).  So it's a push up to that point, right?  Ahhh... but then digest the APR difference that Empyre pointed out and the kama MONK will always surpass the kukri-wielding MONK. 

Of course, it's when the opposing ACs are at the high end, nearly out of reach, when this really becomes noticeable.  Something like an AB of 34 vs. an AC of 50 (or similar proportion).  The monk fighter kukri wielder (I'll limit this to 1H attack to make it simple) uses +34/+29/+24/+19 while the kama fighter monk uses +34/+31/+28/+25/+22/+19 so the kukri guy can threaten crit on first attack only while the kama attack threatens on the first two attacks.  Double the roll opportunities makes a difference. Like I said. It comes down to APR.  And against crit immunes kama is even more dominant because the kama AB will hit more often.

I've seen several builds that use weapons for a monk that bypass the monk progression and I just shrug.  I'll be the first to admit that kamas are boring.  Repeat. BORING! But that's the point.  Monk is such a dominant class, they had to do something to limit its potential by staying thematic.  If you want to dominate as a monk, you have to use the tools the class provides. On my "wish list" would be that shurikens should use the same -3 BAB progression.  At least that way, a monk could use a different attack once in a while without becoming unbalanced yet still remain "monkish" (I've always had a picture of a monk in AD&D as a ninja-like figure but that's just my own warped bias).   Monks would sooner give up their calling than pick up a range weapon, the way its constructed in v3.0.

Well, I don't build PvP toons anymore (they are boring IMO) but if you wanted to morph either the DevCrit or non-DevCrit version into a dueler vs. other DevCritters you'd allocate heavy into CON (with just enough STR to reach DevCrit) and ignore all the other abilities completely.   Great Fort and Epic Fort are automatic.  Skills just to Tumble and Discipline so INT can be left at minimum, ignoring Spellcraft altogether since your chosen adversary will not be a high-level mage.  No stealth or detection since you'd be using monk speed to close asap before the target can displace and before it can finish a taunt action.

As I've stated many times before, when you build a dueler you must first declare your preferred opponent and build specifically to counter its main threat.  That will leave you open to other builds, obviously, but such is the life of a hardcore PvP specialist.  And PvM will be weakened likewise but that is the other cost.

I guess you are referring to OnHit properties on weapons that cannot be resisted by SR but typically DCs rarely go any higher than DC 24 unless the content furnishes some custom DC items.  Also, monsters have a similarly-low DC on their special abilities so little to fear there with your basic monk saves level without feat save enhancements.

The thing is: neither of these builds are all-out mage killers when considering you'll need at least 37 levels of monk plus ISRx10 to assure immunity to all spells that check SR.  These are more a compromise between PvM and PvP lite rather than a serious dueling threat.
